Pre-Civil War 1840's The Zamora Mansion was temporarily used as housing for the Confederate soldiers, until the Albuquerque stronghold was overrun by Union Troops.
Railroad Era -1870's The Zamora Mansion was at the center of downtown Albuquerque commerce. In the 1870's the railroad line was built two miles east of Old Town. At this time, downtown commerce moved toward the railroad crossing near Broadway and Central.
Statehood Era -1912 Zamora Mansion continued to serve as the family residence in the top floor and the south side of the bottom floor. The North side (facing the Plaza) served local market goods and also served as a grocer.
1940's - 1990 Upon the return of Florencio Chavez from serving in the U.S. Army in France during World War II, Florencio updated the current store layout into the modern format it is today.
1990's - 2012 During this period, the Eastern wing of the mansion was converted into self-sustaining properties in order to be leased. Soon afterward, Discovery Balloons and Old Town Hat Boutique began to lease and operate under the Zamora roof. Also, the Western wing of the mansion was converted into restaurant-ready property with a full kitchen and occupancy for 60 patrons.
